Award.AwardTitle: CNH-Ex: An Analysis of Disturbance Interactions and Ecosystem Resilience in the Northern Forest of New England
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will expand a widely used simulation model to study how natural processes interact with changing social and economic pressures to determine the sustainability of forests. Researchers will examine patterns and causes of land use and forest conversion in one of the major remaining forests of the U.S., the woods of northern New York, Vermont, New Hampshire, and Maine. Two main questions are how changes in land ownership affect management decisions, and whether decisions based on short-term economic interests increase the vulnerability of forest to natural disturbances.

The woods of the far northeastern U.S. are a nationally important source of forest products and recreation. This project will help managers anticipate the long-term consequences of alternative policies and better maintain our domestic access to timber and paper. Outcomes will be disseminated to policy makers and land managers via publication in a policy review, a U.S. Forest Service symposium, and the model user group. The project will also train an undergraduate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Within large forest ecosystems supporting economies based on natural resource extraction, the key linkages that are most likely to determine forest dynamics are those that bridge the biophysical and social subsystems. Up until the 1970s, linkages between the biophysical and social were reasonably tight in the rural forests of New England where timber harvesting has a particularly long history. Land use activities influenced and were influenced by forest productivity. Over the last four decades, however, interactions between forest insect damage and mitigation response, and new trends in the social landscape have emerged that may lead to abrupt landscape changes that will negatively impact the spruce-fir forests and timber production in the Northern Forest of the Northeastern U.S.

Key Outcomes: We adapted the process-based forest landscape model (FLM) LANDIS-II to model land use change. Arguably the most widely-used, like other FLMs LANDIS-II was not designed to simulate land use or land cover change. The new software plug-in we developed, LAND USE+, allows users to incorporate maps depicting real or hypothetical landscape changes into LANDIS-II simulations of forest succession. In our application of this new software, our specific interest was understanding the potential for the most likely form of new development in our region (i.e., lakeshore development for second homes) or the next outbreak of spruce budworm to interact with ongoing timber harvesting and induce a widespread change in the compositional state of Maine’s spruce-fir forest. The results of our simulation experiments indicated that even if all ~1,884 km of currently undeveloped and unprotected (i.e., by non-development easement) shoreline around large lakes (i.e., ≥100 acres) were developed over the next 10 years, it would have limited to no effect on area-wide forest dynamics. In contrast, the next outbreak of spruce budworm is likely to alter patterns of forest type change over the next 50 years.

We investigated spatial patterns of spruce-fir distributions and their change under various simulation scenarios using two-dimensional wavelet analyses. By comparing wavelet components derived from initial conditions to 50-year projections, we were able to identify specific areas where changes in spruce-fir distributions were most pronounced, and the characteristic scales at which those changes occurred. Change patterns induced by timber harvesting, and exacerbated by tree mortality caused by spruce budworm, were consistent with loss of spruce-fir forest at fine scales (less than ~10 km). Although locally important, simulated lakeshore development did not induce a significant shift in patterns of spruce-fir dominance beyond those associated with ongoing timber harvesting.

Intellectual Merit: This research project contributed to the understanding of the processes that drive forest change within rural timber-dependent regions. Prior research has established that terrestrial ecosystems can transition abruptly between alternative stable states, with attention generally focused on strongly contrasting vegetation types (e.g., forestland transitioning to grassland). Our research provides a novel contribution by exploring the conditions under which a large forest landscape transitions between states dominated by different assemblages of tree species, and the scale(s) at which transitions are more or less likely to occur.

In support of our simulations, we developed new techniques to map initial forest conditions using field plot data from the USFS Forest Inventory and Analysis Program linked to Landsat satellite imagery and national geospatial data products. Traditional mapping methods generally maximize overall accuracy when calibrating predictive models, but are often biased in their representation of landscape attributes. Biased maps can lead to unreliable or misleading analyses. Our modeling and mapping framework is uniquely designed to simultaneously maximize map accuracy and minimize bias, using advanced machine learning and heuristic optimization algorithms. We also conducted a survey of Maine’s large landowners to better understand what factors influence management decision making. Results suggested that in the case of timber harvesting intentions and behaviors are weakly linked, and interactions with natural resource professionals, peers, and other landowners may be important.

Broader Impacts: This exploratory project brought together a multi-disciplinary team with expertise in forest modeling, human dimensions, landscape and forest ecology, remote sensing, and computer science. Rather than build a project- or system-specific model, we chose to adapt a well-established, open source model to a new problem. The direct connection of this project to the active LANDIS-II developer and user communities ensures broad dissemination of project outcomes and transferability of methods to other regions with similar dynamics, such as the US Pacific Northwest, Southwest, and Southeast. We anticipate the availability of this new modelling capability will stimulate further research, including (1) the strength and directionality of feedbacks between landscape change and landowner decision making and (2) the sensitivity of landowner decisions to changes in forest or market conditions caused by natural disturbance, the actions of neighbors, or other external factors. Addressing these and related topics would improve our understanding of the long-term consequences of human decisions, and a guide for forest policy and best management practices.
